content:
The Act may be cited as the "Iraq Security Agreement Act of 2008". Congress finds that in 2007, President George W. Bush and Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki signed the Declaration of Principles for a Long-Term Relationship between Iraq and the US, aiming to finalize agreements by July 31, 2008, focusing on political, cultural, economic, and security aspects. The Declaration includes security assurances to deter foreign aggression. The Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1991 required the executive branch to report to Congress on security commitments and arrangements. A security commitment is an obligation under international law for the US to defend a country in case of attack, while a security arrangement is a pledge to take action in response to a security threat. These commitments are typically outlined in treaties approved by the Senate. The United States is obligated to consult with countries in case of security threats, outlined in legally-binding agreements like treaties or executive agreements. Agreements with Iraq will address the status of U.S. forces post-2008 and define the bilateral relationship. Lieutenant General Douglas Lute stated that they do not anticipate... Lieutenant General Douglas Lute stated that negotiations under the Declaration of Principles are not expected to require formal inputs from Congress. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS. Congress believes that any agreement outlining the overall bilateral relationship between the US and Iraq, especially one involving a security commitment, should require a joint decision by the executive and legislative branches. Additionally, a short-term extension of the Multi-National Force mandate in Iraq would provide necessary authorities for US forces in accordance with Iraqi law. The short-term extension of the Multi-National Force mandate in Iraq would provide necessary authorities for US forces to carry out their mission. SEC. 4. ANNUAL REPORT ON SECURITY AGREEMENTS. The President must submit a report every February 1 to congressional committees on US security commitments and arrangements with other countries, including formal documents or expressed policies. The President must report annually to congressional committees on US security commitments and arrangements with other countries, assessing the need to continue, modify, or discontinue them in light of changing international security situations. SEC. 5. CONSULTATION WITH CONGRESS.

Within 30 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense must consult with congressional committees on negotiations related to the Declaration of Principles. They are required to keep the committees updated on negotiation progress and share the agreement text before finalizing any security commitment with Iraq.

SEC. 6. PROHIBITIONS. No agreement with security commitments to Iraq can enter into force without following constitutional procedures or new laws enacted after this Act. No funds can be used to implement such agreements unless they comply with constitutional requirements or new laws. The Constitution prohibits Congress from considering any bill that provides budget authority for implementing agreements that violate constitutional procedures or new laws. SEC. 7. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
